text: <@U0169509JG5> Alicia has kindly sent this over, I will flick it over to you!

elements.text: Alicia has kindly sent this over, I will flick it over to you!

text: Ooh I missed that :joy: Monday brain

The only time I've had a client where it served a legitimate purpose was at a large R&D non-profit. They do a ton of government contracting and commercial R&D and whenever we signed deals we would put together a press release or just a general announcement.

We didn't just announce the award, but rather also discussed the research program and why it mattered.

I also imagine for publicly traded companies these types of deals make sense. I know at eBay we just started going public with our partnership with a loan provider besides PayPal.

Here's one of the releases I did with the R&D firm. It's not a client announcement per-se, but rather we're calling out a joint research study the researchers did.

<https://charlescosta.net/index.php/portfolio-item/sri-international-education-development-center-press-release/>

This example from eBay - I had no role in it as I work in Payments, but they took an MLB star and highlighted how they use eBay as a customer.

<https://www.ebayinc.com/stories/news/mlb-pitcher-pat-neshek-shares-how-he-amassed-a-seven-figure-trading-card-collection-in-premiere-episode-of-ebays-uncommon-series/>

Overall I'd say if you sign a deal with a large client, I'd use it as a case study once you've shown results. If you jump the gun, announce the large deal and six months later said customer is gone, it's not going to look very good.

attachments.title: Demonstrating The Effects of Educational Content on Childhood Education | Charles Costa
attachments.fallback: Charles Costa: Demonstrating The Effects of Educational Content on Childhood Education | Charles Costa

attachments.title: MLB Pitcher Pat Neshek Shares How He Amassed a Seven Figure Trading Card Collection in Premiere Episode of eBay’s “Uncommon” Series
attachments.text: Video diaries celebrate eBay’s buyers and sellers’ unique stories and their “uncommon” finds on the marketplace With over 50,000 autographed cards in his collection, eBay’s inaugural episode highlights Neshek’s affinity for baseball trading cards and how time on the mound inspired his passion for collecting.
attachments.fallback: MLB Pitcher Pat Neshek Shares How He Amassed a Seven Figure Trading Card Collection in Premiere Episode of eBay’s “Uncommon” Series

elements.text:
The only time I've had a client where it served a legitimate purpose was at a large R&D non-profit. They do a ton of government contracting and commercial R&D and whenever we signed deals we would put together a press release or just a general announcement.

We didn't just announce the award, but rather also discussed the research program and why it mattered.

I also imagine for publicly traded companies these types of deals make sense. I know at eBay we just started going public with our partnership with a loan provider besides PayPal.

Here's one of the releases I did with the R&D firm. It's not a client announcement per-se, but rather we're calling out a joint research study the researchers did.
This example from eBay - I had no role in it as I work in Payments, but they took an MLB star and highlighted how they use eBay as a customer.

Overall I'd say if you sign a deal with a large client, I'd use it as a case study once you've shown results. If you jump the gun, announce the large deal and six months later said customer is gone, it's not going to look very good.
